comments.commentBody:
Jeez, I worked and worked on this puzzle until a little bit after the timer gave up. I had everything sussed out except the box with the "60" in it. I checked all my letters, and they were OK ... just the one blank.

I was dying to put STAGNATION in (BOS'N is a word) and tried the whole alphabet without luck. I ended up asking REVEAL to put me out of my misery.

I've been around boats quite a bit, but YARE was new to me. The across answer is a bit of a made-up word, but it made me smile.

-- jpgaskell
I met Gary in  Florida a few years ago, a gentleman and great player. God speed Gary.

This article omits the issue of debt. Upper level private colleges now charge ~ $53,000 a year. That does not include living expenses. Of course there will be some financial aid but most is in the forms of loans not grants. Imagine a college student starting in the fall of 2011 and graduating in 2015. Let's assume college tuition continues during that time to rise ahead of inflation by 3 - 4 %.

It's reasonable that a fair number of students without wealthy parents will graduate with ~ $160,000 in debt. Assuming a mix of federal and private loans, graduating students will be left with a monthly payment of ~ $1,500 - $2,000.

For state universities the situation is different. However it's much more likely that a student will take 5 or more years to graduate (the majority do). Debt payments for the more expensive state schools (assuming in-state tuition) will be ~ $800 a month.

The debt levels are crippling! Yes on paper the graduating student earns more money but not necessarily in practice. Also note: Student loans are almost impossible to discharge in bankruptcy. And don't forget that real incomes for college graduates have stagnated since 2000 in real terms.

I don't understand why articles on future student wages don't consider very high levels of student debt.

I loved this article. In my home town (Minneapolis), over the past 25 years, I have witnessed the demise of cheap studio+rehersal space. In addition to gentrification's role, Legions of hobbyists and hipsters (with generous parents) take up available work space and drive up rents.

Responding to comment #36: I have a 2nd home in France and decided to take my cat with me because I came for 3 months, too long to be away from each other. I flew Air Canada - Air France rates for taking a pet were double - and the experience was extremely positive. I booked myself and my cat's tiokets several months ahead, checked the airline website as well as regulations for bringing a pet to France (and bringing her back to Canada), talked to the vet a couple of times - who warned against sedatives because my cat could get sick from them. I was more concerned about how she was going to make it through getting to the airport 3 hours ahead (which turned out to be totally unnecessary), sitting on a plane for 8 hours (she would hates being in her carrier), and then the 4.5 hr drive from Paris to my home. And of course the usual nightmare of going thru security at CDG.
None of my fears was realized! My cat was a perfect traveller (a little whiny but not as much as the screeching babies on board). I did take her to the toilet on the plane a couple of times so I could pet and reassure her. French customs oohed and ahhed over her (and didn't even ask for her documents), and we both made it to my home with no "accidents" and in good spirits! I am now more relaxed about the prospect of going back to Canada. My advice: talk to the airline directly when booking, see your vet, check and recheck the destination country's rules, get the documentation in order, and have a glass of wine on the plane :) Bon voyage!

The whole crisis is best blamed on the party that let the credit bubble grow so fast and so far.  That of course hs to be the Federal Reserve System whose responsibility it was/is to never let that happen.   just go to the FDIC website and plot out the long term loan growth rate.  Joe

we know that wage arbitrage is still a factor - corporate profits are up, there are more American Billionaires controlling more trillions than ever,  worker stress is up, wages down - temps and per diems with no benefits are filling the ranks of corporate world and even the widely touted health care 'growth industry' - just ask anyone who has put down good money to get certified as a radiology or lab tech - or been down sized from any industry - the global middle class may be growing, but American middle class is still struggling and recovery is not in sight -

So, if I understand well the bold reconstructors of reality, Lehman Brothers was a subprime borrower?

Verily, the debt load could not be carried anymore, my many actors, some individual, some institutional. A trigger was the rise of energy cost, but the simple rise of ARM payments could have done it too.

The crisis is indeed going on, because the banks have no been re-regulated into their fiduciary mission, which is to create money (through lending) to serve the economy. As it, they serve themselves by speculating financially, or by borrowing government money to invest with the government, a self referential ecstasy.
http://patriceayme.wordpress.com/

Regardless of what happened in the US, the whole 'gummat did it' story fails to take into account Iceland, Ireland and the UK, all of which experienced the exact same thing with no Fannie, no Freddie, no CRA and (shock, horror, Austrians!) much tighter monetary policy.

Y'all's just jealous because I got to be one and two for a whole day. And I stand by that being fiscally conservative and socially liberal are incongruent. Social programs, just like everything else need money. Many people need a hand. I signed my house back a week ago, gonna have a yard sale and go to Haiti and volunteer in an orphanage for a while, with religious zealots, but not everybody who is losing their shirt can make such a radical plan. I have no kids.

True, and I am amazed again and again how even respected economists keep on misunderstanding data, or overlook the basics and make things complex, when the data in its essence gives us the simplest explanations. Thank you for making this clear!
That 'fiscally cons/socially lib' is code for I'm a republican, but I want you to think I am cool.

Hey Paul

You might find this an interesting discussion on the effects of the financial crisis...

http://golemxiv-credo.blogspot.com/2011/05/new-normal.html

(Hat tip to Petey over at The Big Picture)

The statement the "government did it" isn't that far off the mark. It's just not the big, bad governement of and for the people that helped to put us in our current state, but the governement of and for the hyper-wealthy that has us privitizing profits and socializing losses.

Here's George Carlin for a few sad laughs...

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hYIC0eZYEtI&feature=youtu.be

That's the belief of the Tea Party.  And this isn't a point that be argued successfully in a town hall meeting.  If people are paid to lie about complicated matters, then they will probably be successful in selling whatever it is they are selling.

Of course: AEI, Heritage and the other conservative think tanks are essential to the project of misleading citizens because that is not only required to mask the malfeasance of elites it is part of the larger project of control. That is, lies with the patina of plausibility are required in abundance until a sufficient number of people have been trained in newspeak and doublethink to make the system easier to maintain.

Propaganda, spying and swift punishment for deviance would remain constant features of such a system regardless of course. As George Orwell observed in "1984:"

"[Doublethink] The power of holding two contradictory beliefs in one's mind simultaneously, and accepting both of them....To tell deliberate lies while genuinely believing in them, to forget any fact that has become inconvenient, and then, when it becomes necessary again, to draw it back from oblivion for just so long as it is needed, to deny the existence of objective reality and all the while to take account of the reality which one denies ..."

Conforming loans (Fannie/Freddy) and poor people (CRA) brought the entire financial to its knees, liar loans and derivatives from the private sector had little to do with it, and we've always been at war with Eastasia.
Enjoy!

Mr. Pinto seems to believe that government is the problem, not the solution. So addressing his data is not really addressing his underlying belief.

Right now, I would agree with Mr. Pinto that government is the problem. But I would be looking for ways for the government to reflect the public interest, rather than trying to destroy government (and destroy its associated potential to serve our society as a whole.)

Looks to me like sunrise across the Bay of Naples. Isn't that the Castel dell'Ovo on the left? I was in the Navy and we started married life there 52 years ago. We lived in a villa up the road on Via Posillipo, where it was reputed Virgil once lived. I told Margaret we'd probably never get back and we haven't. Have a safe trip home.
J. Maron

We've known for a long time that the bulk of bad loans came from the private sector, and that Fannie and Freddie's problems were caused by the bubble, not by its lending practices. (And, of course, that the CRA has absolutely nothing to do with the crisis).

See, e.g.,
http://www.mcclatchydc.com/2008/10/12/53802/private-sector-loans-not-fan... ("|Private sector loans, not Fannie or Freddie, triggered crisis," Sunday, October 12, 2008, David Goldstein and Kevin G. Hall, McClatchy Newspapers) or http://modeledbehavior.com/2010/08/27/fannie-freddie-acquitted/ ("Fannie / Freddie Acquitted," August 27th, 2010, Karl Smith, Modeled Behavior).

Heck, Bush's Fed chairman Alan Greenspan, Bush's SEC chairman Christopher Cox, and Bush's Treasury secretary John Snow would tell you that (and did, to a House committee hearing a few years back).

The Republican Party-- and the right-wing paramedia like the American Spectator and Rush Limbaugh and GOP PR firms like AEI-- have abandoned rational thought, opting instead to parrot a small handful of anti-government talking points crafted decades ago in an effort to gain votes from whites resentful of the federal government's efforts to end segregation.

That, with the possible additional reason of enriching AEI's paymasters, is the only way to understand why people like Peter Wallison and Edward Pinto are lying about the causes of the crisis.

The propaganda effort to confuse people by combining “subprime and other high-risk mortgages” is quite reminiscent of the right-wing effort to lie about Social Security's long-term status by grouping together "Social Security and Medicare" (which of course, ignores the fact that the long-term problems with Medicare are the consequence of US-only astronomical and growing health care costs).

These folks simply prefer lies to truth.

Wouldn't you agree that the rating agencies were at the heart of the problem? Investments that they rated as AAA turned out to be trash. The rating agencies are the product of government action, not an unfettered market. It seems to me the government is still very much to blame for the mess we are in.

And let's not forget that Bush's reckless spending turned Clinton's surplus into an enormous deficit and wreaked havoc with an economy that had been doing pretty well up to that point.
looks like Bahia, but where is it?

There's an excellent paper by the San Francisco Fed about the performance of loans under the Community Reinvestment Act; they actually defaulted at much lower rates than private label mortgages. http://www.frbsf.org/publications/community/wpapers/2008/wp08-05.pdf

Reminds me of the book that I am reading titled "Overdosed America" by John Abramson, He documents that the drug companies gave misleading data to back up their claims that the new (and expensive) drugs were affective, when in reality the drugs caused a lot of dangerous side effects.

Willful ignorance is shameful

.

Happened upon your 11/30/09 column that I printed out.
1. "A bolder economic policy earlier this year might have led to a turnaound, but what we actually got were half measures. As a result, unemployment is likely to stay at its current level for a year or more." Now, 1.5 years after, unemployment still far too high.
2. "These economic half-measures hae landed the Obama administration in a trap: much of the political establishment now sees stimulus as having been discredited by events, so it is pretty hard to come back and scale the policy up to where it should have been in the first place..."
3. "The result, then, will be high unemployment leading into the 2010 elections, and corresponding Democatic losses. These losses will be worse because Obama, by pursuing a uniformly pro-banker policy without even a gesture to the popular anger over bailouts, has ceded populist energy to the right and demoralized the movement that brought him to power."
4. " Along with this will come a process of defining prosperity down."
5. "So what I see is years of terrible job markets, combined with political paralysis."

"Hope I wrong with all this."

Sorry Paul, you were correct. Welcome home! Write on!!
